    On Mon, Apr 13, 2009 at 11:44 AM, John S <phenom_investigator@yaho=

      The problem we run into is what actually constitut=
es evidence of spirit communication? This is the heart of the matter. As I =
said in the other thread, one cannot simply assume that unexplained informa=
tion defacto proves spirit communication or even external sources. 

      =
The reason is simple. It is quite possible for internal and/or external inf=
luences to be exerted in an experiment. Let us say you are doing an experim=
ent and you are the only participant. We'll set aside the obvious challenge=
 of reporting credibility for the moment. How do you truly know it's not yo=
u and even worse, how do you know who in fact the external communicator is?=
 Simply knowing facts is not sufficient. Especially in cases where PK may b=
e in play (such as the Ouija example) a remote PK agent could be influencin=
g the planchette. Before ruling this out, consider that the very notion tha=
t anyone is moving anything is problematic for many people. And spirit comm=
unication pushes the edge of the belief envelope for others. In the end, al=
l of this is some form of anomalous phenomena. You could know things of whi=
ch you are unaware. Consider that you might be clairvoyant and not even rea=
lize it. If you were to externalize this through a latent PK mechanism, bin=
go, you are the agent and the source of information. Yet to all appearances=
 the information came from elsewhere and you therefore presume it must be e=
xternal to yourself, which in this example would not be true..



      I w=
as taking advantage of the physical nature of the experiment I proposed. Un=
fortunately this is what is required if one wishes to remove reliance on be=
lief systems alone. This is what many in the field are looking for. From my=
 own work with mediums and other sensitives, I have learned the perils and =
the potential pitfalls with our own perceptual systems, memories and recall=
. All of this works against us in even the most trivial experimental set up=
, which is unfortunate but true. This is yet one more reason to exercise ca=
ution with solely anecdotal experimental outcomes. You will find that indep=
endent historical validation is actualy pretty tricky, as I have said befor=
e, because it often is not simply factual in nature. It tends to be more ab=
out emotions and feelings and that's where specifically identifying an indi=
vidual gets dicey.



      I wish you all the best in your efforts, whatev=
er path you may chose.



        JS
